title: 2 Kings Chapter 14 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Kings chapter 14 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Kings Chapter 14 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Kings Chapter 14.

questions.question: Who began to reign in the second year of Joash son of Jehoahaz king of Israel?
options: Amaziah son of Joash king of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: Amaziah son of Joash king of Judah
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:1 states that Amaziah the son of Joash king of Judah reigned in the second year of Joash son of Jehoahaz king of Israel.

questions.question: How old was Amaziah when he began to reign, according to 2 Kings 14?
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty and five years old
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:2 states Amaziah was twenty and five years old when he began to reign.

questions.question: What was Amaziah’s mother's name?
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoaddan
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:2 provides the name of Amaziah’s mother as Jehoaddan of Jerusalem.

questions.question: Did Amaziah remove the high places where people sacrificed and burnt incense?
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:4 states the high places were not taken away and people still sacrificed and burnt incense there.

questions.question: What did Amaziah do to his servants who killed his father?
questions.correctAnswer: He slew them
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:5 says that Amaziah slew his servants who had slain his father after his kingdom was confirmed.

questions.question: According to the law of Moses, did Amaziah kill the children of the murderers?
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:6 explains that Amaziah did not kill the children of the murderers, in accordance with the law of Moses.

questions.question: How many Edomites did Amaziah kill in the valley of salt?
questions.correctAnswer: Ten thousand
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:7 states Amaziah slew ten thousand Edomites in the valley of salt.

questions.question: What new name did Amaziah give to Selah after capturing it?
questions.correctAnswer: Joktheel
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:7 tells us Amaziah called Selah 'Joktheel' after he took it by war.

questions.question: Who did Amaziah send messengers to, inviting to look one another in the face?
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoash king of Israel
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:8 shows Amaziah sent messengers to Jehoash king of Israel with that invitation.

questions.question: What metaphor did Jehoash use in his reply to Amaziah?
questions.correctAnswer: The thistle and the cedar
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:9 records Jehoash comparing a thistle to a cedar to illustrate his point.

questions.question: True or False: Amaziah heeded Jehoash’s warning and did not go to war.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:11 states Amaziah would not hear Jehoash’s warning, leading to their confrontation.

questions.question: Where did Amaziah and Jehoash meet to face each other?
questions.correctAnswer: Bethshemesh
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:11 says they looked one another in the face at Bethshemesh, which belonged to Judah.

questions.question: What was the outcome of the battle between Judah and Israel?
options: Judah was put to the worse and fled
questions.correctAnswer: Judah was put to the worse and fled
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:12 reports Judah was defeated and fled every man to their tents.

questions.question: Jehoash king of Israel broke down the wall of Jerusalem from the gate of Ephraim to what gate?
questions.correctAnswer: The corner gate
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:13 states Jehoash broke down the wall from the gate of Ephraim to the corner gate.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'And Jehoash king of Israel took Amaziah king of Judah, the son of Joash... at ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: Bethshemesh
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:13 mentions Jehoash took Amaziah at Bethshemesh.

medium.title: 2 Kings Chapter 14 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Kings Chapter 14 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is dealing with bitterness and hardship. Based on 2 Kings 14, what biblical truth would you share about God's care in difficult times?
options: God sees the affliction and will not abandon His people
God ignores the suffering of His people
God expects people to suffer without help
questions.correctAnswer: God sees the affliction and will not abandon His people
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:26-27 teach us that the LORD saw Israel's affliction and did not blot out their name, but saved them. This shows God's care and faithfulness even in hardship.

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 14 teach us about humility when facing victory and success?
options: Do not let success make your heart proud; stay humble
questions.correctAnswer: Do not let success make your heart proud; stay humble
questions.explanation: Jehoash warned Amaziah in 2 Kings 14:9-10 not to let his heart be lifted up after victory over Edom, teaching humility and caution against pride.

questions.question: A believer asks how to respond to betrayal or wrongdoing within the family. What does 2 Kings 14 suggest about justice and mercy?
options: Punish the wrongdoers but spare their children
Punish both the wrongdoers and their children
questions.correctAnswer: Punish the wrongdoers but spare their children
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:5-6 shows Amaziah executing his father's murderers but sparing their children, following the Mosaic law about individual responsibility.

questions.question: What biblical principle about obedience to God’s commands can be learned from Amaziah’s failure to remove high places?
options: Partial obedience is not enough; complete obedience is required
Ignoring God's commands has no consequences
Only outward actions matter, not inner faith
questions.correctAnswer: Partial obedience is not enough; complete obedience is required
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:3-4 describes Amaziah doing right but not removing high places, showing incomplete obedience which affects spiritual life.

questions.question: How does this passage illustrate the importance of trusting God rather than relying on human strength in conflict?
options: Ignoring God’s warnings leads to defeat
Conflict is best resolved by pride
questions.correctAnswer: Ignoring God’s warnings leads to defeat
questions.explanation: Amaziah ignored Jehoash’s warning (2 Kings 14:8-11) and suffered defeat (2 Kings 14:12-13), teaching reliance on God and wise counsel.

questions.question: When facing opposition, what lesson about perseverance can be drawn from Amaziah’s story in 2 Kings 14?
options: Perseverance requires humility and listening to counsel
Opposition means God has abandoned you
Ignore all advice and act alone
questions.correctAnswer: Perseverance requires humility and listening to counsel
questions.explanation: Amaziah’s refusal to listen led to his defeat and death (2 Kings 14:11-19), showing the need for humble perseverance with God’s guidance.

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 14 teach about the importance of legacy and godly leadership in family and community?
options: Godly leadership impacts future generations positively
Leadership has no effect on others
Leaders should only focus on themselves
questions.correctAnswer: Godly leadership impacts future generations positively
questions.explanation: The records of Jehoash, Amaziah, and Jeroboam (2 Kings 14:15,18,28) emphasize the significance of godly leadership and its record for posterity.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with contentment after achieving success. What biblical truth from 2 Kings 14 would encourage them?
options: Be content and humble rather than prideful
Always seek more glory for self
questions.correctAnswer: Be content and humble rather than prideful
questions.explanation: Jehoash’s warning to Amaziah (2 Kings 14:9-10) teaches humility and contentment instead of pride after success.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Kings 14, Amaziah completely removed all idolatrous high places during his reign.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:4 states that Amaziah did not remove the high places, and the people still sacrificed there.

questions.question: True or False: The Bible teaches in 2 Kings 14 that children should be punished for the sins of their parents.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:6 explains the LORD’s command that children shall not be put to death for their fathers' sins, emphasizing individual responsibility.

questions.question: A believer asks about the importance of prayer and seeking God’s guidance before making decisions. How does 2 Kings 14 illustrate this?
options: Ignoring God’s guidance leads to downfall
Human wisdom is superior to God’s
questions.correctAnswer: Ignoring God’s guidance leads to downfall
questions.explanation: Amaziah ignored Jehoash’s warning and God’s implied counsel, leading to defeat and death, showing the need to seek God’s guidance (2 Kings 14:9-19).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to 2 Kings 14, the LORD saved Israel by the hand of ______, despite their affliction.
questions.correctAnswer: Jeroboam the son of Joash
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:27 states that the LORD saved Israel by Jeroboam son of Joash despite their troubles.

questions.question: What does 2 Kings 14 teach about the role of faithfulness to God’s word in leadership?
options: Leaders must follow God’s commands to lead well
Leaders can ignore God’s word without consequence
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must follow God’s commands to lead well
questions.explanation: Amaziah did right but did not fully obey God (2 Kings 14:3-4), and Jeroboam did evil (2 Kings 14:24), showing the importance of obedience.

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 14 demonstrate the importance of reconciliation and forgiveness within a community?
options: Amaziah’s killing of his father’s murderers shows justice balanced with mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Amaziah’s killing of his father’s murderers shows justice balanced with mercy
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:5-6 shows Amaziah avenged his father but spared the murderers’ children, balancing justice and mercy.

questions.question: What practical lesson about stewardship and integrity can be learned from Jehoash’s actions after defeating Amaziah?
options: Respect for what belongs to God and the people is important
Taking everything without care is acceptable
Stewardship is only about personal gain
questions.correctAnswer: Respect for what belongs to God and the people is important
questions.explanation: Jehoash took treasures from the temple and king’s house (2 Kings 14:14), but this action warns us about integrity and stewardship of what is holy.

hard.title: 2 Kings Chapter 14 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Kings Chapter 14.

questions.question: In 2 Kings 14, Amaziah spared the children of his father's murderers. Which Mosaic law principle did he follow in doing this?
options: The fathers shall not be put to death for the children
questions.correctAnswer: The fathers shall not be put to death for the children
questions.explanation: Amaziah spared the children of the murderers based on the law in the book of Moses that states 'The fathers shall not be put to death for the children, nor the children be put to death for the fathers; but every man shall be put to death for his own sin' (2 Kings 14:6).

questions.question: What was the age of Amaziah when he began to reign as king of Judah according to 2 Kings 14?
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty and five years old
questions.explanation: The text explicitly states that Amaziah was twenty and five years old when he began to reign (2 Kings 14:2).

questions.question: Jehoash king of Israel compared Amaziah to which plants in his message warning him?
options: A fig tree and a vine
A palm tree and an olive
questions.correctAnswer: A thistle and a cedar
questions.explanation: Jehoash used the imagery of a thistle and a cedar in Lebanon to illustrate his warning to Amaziah (2 Kings 14:9).

questions.question: Which city did Amaziah capture from Edom and rename, as recorded in 2 Kings 14?
questions.correctAnswer: Selah, renamed Joktheel
questions.explanation: Amaziah took Selah by war and called it Joktheel (2 Kings 14:7).

questions.question: How many years did Amaziah reign in Jerusalem according to 2 Kings 14?
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty and nine years
questions.explanation: The chapter states Amaziah reigned twenty and nine years in Jerusalem (2 Kings 14:2).

questions.question: What was the outcome of the battle between Amaziah king of Judah and Jehoash king of Israel?
options: Judah was defeated and fled to their tents
Judah defeated Israel and took prisoners
They made peace and exchanged hostages
questions.correctAnswer: Judah was defeated and fled to their tents
questions.explanation: Judah was put to the worse before Israel, and they fled every man to their tents (2 Kings 14:12).

questions.question: What significant action did Jehoash of Israel take after defeating Amaziah and entering Jerusalem?
options: He broke down the wall of Jerusalem for four hundred cubits
He destroyed the temple of the LORD
He crowned himself king of Judah
He executed the nobles of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: He broke down the wall of Jerusalem for four hundred cubits
questions.explanation: Jehoash broke down the wall of Jerusalem from the gate of Ephraim unto the corner gate, four hundred cubits (2 Kings 14:13).

questions.question: After Jehoash's victory over Judah, what did he take from the house of the LORD and the king's house?
options: All the gold, silver, and vessels, plus hostages
questions.correctAnswer: All the gold, silver, and vessels, plus hostages
questions.explanation: Jehoash took all the gold and silver, all the vessels found in the house of the LORD and the king’s treasures, and hostages (2 Kings 14:14).

questions.question: Which prophet's word did Jeroboam son of Joash fulfill when restoring Israel's borders, as mentioned in 2 Kings 14?
questions.correctAnswer: Jonah son of Amittai
questions.explanation: Jeroboam restored the coast of Israel according to the word of the LORD spoken by Jonah son of Amittai (2 Kings 14:25).

questions.question: What does 2 Kings 14 reveal about the LORD’s attitude toward Israel despite their affliction?
options: The LORD did not blot out Israel's name but saved them through Jeroboam
The LORD abandoned Israel to their enemies
The LORD immediately restored Israel’s kingdom
The LORD punished all Israelites without exception
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD did not blot out Israel's name but saved them through Jeroboam
questions.explanation: Despite Israel's bitterness and affliction, the LORD did not blot out their name but saved them by the hand of Jeroboam (2 Kings 14:26-27).

questions.question: True or False: Amaziah removed the high places and stopped sacrifices there during his reign.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The high places were not taken away, and the people still sacrificed and burnt incense on them (2 Kings 14:4).

questions.question: What was the relationship between Jehoash king of Israel and Jehoash king of Judah?
questions.correctAnswer: They were contemporaries and adversaries
questions.explanation: Jehoash king of Israel and Amaziah king of Judah (son of Jehoash) were contemporaries who fought against each other (2 Kings 14:8-11).

questions.question: Which city did Amaziah flee to after a conspiracy was made against him, where he was ultimately killed?
questions.correctAnswer: Lachish
questions.explanation: Amaziah fled to Lachish after a conspiracy, but they sent men and killed him there (2 Kings 14:19).

questions.question: How does the narrative of Amaziah's reign and death in 2 Kings 14 foreshadow the instability often seen in the Davidic line?
options: Through conspiracy, flight, and violent death within Judah
By peaceful succession and long reign
questions.correctAnswer: Through conspiracy, flight, and violent death within Judah
questions.explanation: Amaziah’s conspiracy, flight to Lachish, and violent death reflect the recurring theme of instability and internal strife in the Davidic dynasty (2 Kings 14:19-20).

questions.question: Who succeeded Amaziah as king of Judah and at what age, according to 2 Kings 14?
questions.correctAnswer: Azariah, at sixteen years old
questions.explanation: The people of Judah made Azariah king at sixteen years old after Amaziah’s death (2 Kings 14:21).

theological.title: 2 Kings Chapter 14 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Kings Chapter 14 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 2 Kings 14, how did Amaziah reign in relation to his father Joash and King David?
options: He did right in the sight of the LORD, but not like David; he followed Joash's ways
He was completely faithful like David and Joash
He sinned more than his father Joash and David
He followed only David's example, not Joash's
questions.correctAnswer: He did right in the sight of the LORD, but not like David; he followed Joash's ways
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:3 states Amaziah did right before the LORD, yet not like David; rather, he followed all the ways of Joash his father. This shows partial faithfulness consistent with other biblical examples where kings are judged by their adherence to God's law (1 Kings 15:11, 2 Chronicles 25:2, Psalm 78:72, Acts 13:22).

questions.question: What does Amaziah’s decision to kill his father's murderers but not their children illustrate about God's justice?
options: God commands individual responsibility for sin, not generational punishment
It was a political strategy unrelated to divine law
Children should always be punished for their parents' sins
Amaziah acted out of personal mercy, not law
questions.correctAnswer: God commands individual responsibility for sin, not generational punishment
questions.explanation: Verse 6 cites the Mosaic law stating no one shall be put to death for another's sin but for their own. This reflects divine justice emphasizing individual accountability (Deuteronomy 24:16, Ezekiel 18:20, Jeremiah 31:29-30, Romans 2:6).

questions.question: Which city did Amaziah capture from Edom, and what new name did he give it?
questions.correctAnswer: Selah, renamed Joktheel
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:7 records Amaziah took Selah by war and renamed it Joktheel. This renaming signifies divine victory and God's sovereignty over nations (Genesis 17:5, Joshua 6:26, Isaiah 62:2, Revelation 21:2).

questions.question: What warning did Jehoash king of Israel give to Amaziah about confronting him?
options: He likened Amaziah to a thistle challenging a cedar, doomed to be crushed
He warned Amaziah of God's judgment if he attacked
He promised to make peace if Amaziah retreated
He invited Amaziah to form an alliance against Edom
questions.correctAnswer: He likened Amaziah to a thistle challenging a cedar, doomed to be crushed
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 14:9-10, Jehoash uses a parable comparing Amaziah to a thistle that dared to challenge a mighty cedar but was trampled by a wild beast. This illustrates God's sovereignty in protecting his chosen leaders and warns against prideful rebellion (Proverbs 16:18, Isaiah 10:33, James 4:6, 1 Corinthians 10:12).

questions.question: What was the outcome of the battle between Jehoash of Israel and Amaziah of Judah?
options: Judah was defeated and fled to their tents
Judah won decisively and captured Samaria
The battle ended in a stalemate
Amaziah was killed on the battlefield
questions.correctAnswer: Judah was defeated and fled to their tents
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:12 states Judah was put to the worse before Israel, and the soldiers fled. This defeat shows the consequences of pride and disobedience to God (1 Samuel 17:47, 2 Chronicles 25:16-17, Psalm 33:10-12, Proverbs 21:30).

questions.question: After defeating Amaziah, what did Jehoash do to Jerusalem?
options: He broke down the wall from the gate of Ephraim to the corner gate for 400 cubits
He took the city without any damage
He rebuilt the walls stronger than before
questions.correctAnswer: He broke down the wall from the gate of Ephraim to the corner gate for 400 cubits
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:13 describes Jehoash breaking down a significant section of Jerusalem’s wall, demonstrating the consequences of ungodly rebellion and defeat (Nehemiah 2:17-20, Jeremiah 52:7, Ezekiel 4:1-3, Revelation 21:12).

questions.question: What significant items did Jehoash take from Jerusalem after his victory?
options: Gold, silver, vessels from the temple, treasures of the king's house, and hostages
questions.correctAnswer: Gold, silver, vessels from the temple, treasures of the king's house, and hostages
questions.explanation: Verse 14 recounts Jehoash taking precious metals and sacred vessels along with hostages, symbolizing the spoiling of the temple and royal authority (1 Samuel 4:11, 2 Chronicles 28:24, Jeremiah 7:14, Revelation 11:2).

questions.question: How long did Amaziah reign in Jerusalem before his death?
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty-nine years
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:2 states Amaziah reigned twenty-nine years in Jerusalem. This duration reflects God’s allowance for his kingship despite imperfections (2 Chronicles 25:1, Psalm 90:10, Ecclesiastes 3:1-2, Acts 13:21).

questions.question: What happened to Amaziah at the end of his reign according to 2 Kings 14?
options: He was slain at Lachish after fleeing a conspiracy
He abdicated in favor of his son
questions.correctAnswer: He was slain at Lachish after fleeing a conspiracy
questions.explanation: Verses 19-20 record a conspiracy against Amaziah; he fled to Lachish but was killed there. This shows the instability caused by sin and rebellion (Psalm 7:15-16, Proverbs 11:21, Jeremiah 38:7-13, Matthew 26:31).

questions.question: Who succeeded Amaziah as king of Judah, and at what age did he begin to reign?
questions.correctAnswer: Azariah, at sixteen years old
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:21 tells us all the people of Judah made Azariah king at sixteen after Amaziah. This aligns with biblical patterns of dynastic succession and God's providence over kingship (1 Kings 15:1-2, 2 Chronicles 26:1, Psalm 2:6-9, Daniel 2:21).

questions.question: What was Jeroboam son of Joash's overall evaluation in the sight of the LORD?
options: He did evil and did not depart from the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat
He was righteous and restored true worship
He was neutral with no notable sins
He reformed Israel according to God's law
questions.correctAnswer: He did evil and did not depart from the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:24 states Jeroboam son of Joash did evil and continued Israel’s idolatry begun by Jeroboam son of Nebat. This shows the persistent rebellion against God's covenant (1 Kings 12:28-30, Hosea 1:4-5, Romans 11:2, Revelation 2:14).

questions.question: How did the LORD respond to the affliction of Israel during Jeroboam’s reign?
options: He did not blot out Israel's name but saved them by Jeroboam's hand
He completely destroyed Israel for their sins
He sent a prophet to exile them immediately
questions.correctAnswer: He did not blot out Israel's name but saved them by Jeroboam's hand
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:27 emphasizes God's mercy despite Israel's suffering, preserving their name through Jeroboam’s leadership. This reflects God's covenant faithfulness and sovereignty (Exodus 3:7-8, Psalm 106:45, Isaiah 43:1-3, Romans 9:22-23).

questions.question: Which prophet’s word did Jeroboam son of Joash fulfill by restoring Israel’s borders?
questions.correctAnswer: Jonah son of Amittai
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 14:25 records Jeroboam restored Israel’s borders as prophesied by Jonah son of Amittai. This highlights God's use of prophets to guide history and fulfill covenant promises (Jonah 1:1-2, Isaiah 55:11, Acts 13:34-35, Hebrews 1:1-2).

questions.question: What theological principle about God’s patience and justice is illustrated by the LORD’s preservation of Israel in this chapter?
options: God delays full judgment to allow for repentance and maintains His covenant promises
God ignores sin until it becomes overwhelming
God’s justice is arbitrary and unpredictable
God’s mercy cancels out all consequences of sin
questions.correctAnswer: God delays full judgment to allow for repentance and maintains His covenant promises
questions.explanation: The LORD’s sparing of Israel despite severe affliction (2 Kings 14:26-27) demonstrates His longsuffering, justice, and covenant faithfulness (Exodus 34:6-7, 2 Peter 3:9, Lamentations 3:22-23, Romans 11:22).

questions.question: What does the conflict between Jehoash and Amaziah teach about human pride and reliance on God?
options: Pride leads to downfall when one relies on self rather than God's guidance
Human strength alone suffices for triumph
God supports those who fight regardless of their motives
questions.correctAnswer: Pride leads to downfall when one relies on self rather than God's guidance
questions.explanation: Jehoash’s parable and Amaziah’s refusal to heed it (2 Kings 14:9-11) show the danger of prideful rebellion against God’s will, echoing biblical warnings (Proverbs 16:18, Isaiah 2:11, James 4:6, 1 Peter 5:5).
